meanings.def: quick at learning and understanding things
examples: a clever child
Clever girl!
He's too clever by half, if you ask me (= it annoys me or makes me suspicious).
They're not clever enough to find the code.
clever at something He's always been clever at crosswords.
clever at doing something She's clever at getting what she wants.
clever with something He's clever with his hands.
I became quite clever at making tasty meals out of nothing.
I'm not very clever at maths.

meanings.def: showing intelligence or skill, for example in the design of an object, in an idea or somebody’s actions
examples: a clever trick
What a clever idea!
That wasn't very clever (= what you just did wasn't sensible), was it?
clever marketing
Admitting her mistake may have been quite a clever move on her part.
it is clever of somebody to do something It was clever of him to have spotted the mistake.
How clever of you to work it out!
it is clever to do something 'Young people think it's clever to do that sort of thing, and it isn't,' she said.
clever of somebody Letting him think it was his idea was very clever of you.
That wasn't a very clever thing to do.
a simple yet fiendishly clever idea
a clever little gadget
The present owners have made clever use of the limited space in this room.

meanings.def: quick with words in a way that annoys people or does not show respect
examples: Don't you get clever with me!

meanings.def: to act in a clever way to get what you want, sometimes tricking somebody
examples: Suzie realized that she had to box clever. She had to let Adam think she trusted him.

idioms.def: to act in a clever way to get what you want, sometimes tricking somebody
examples: Suzie realized that she had to box clever. She had to let Adam think she trusted him.

related: be as clever, stupid, etc. as they come
